4261c90a-fb1a-4d50-87fa-220fb3b89680.content:
What do you know about optimization problems? 
Create a table storing the different categories, types, forms, their names, descriptions and order it from most appearances (10) to less appearances (1). 
Provide the result as CSV code-block (file) with header "Rank,Name,Abbreviation,Description,Solvability,Example,Appearances"

content_list.content:
```csv
Rank,Name,Abbreviation,Description,Solvability,Example,Appearances
1,Linear Programming,LP,Optimization of a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.,Polynomial time (e.g., Simplex, Interior Point),Maximize profit given resource constraints,10
2,Nonlinear Programming,NLP,Objective function or constraints are nonlinear; generalization of LP.,Varies (local/global solvers),Minimize energy in a physical system,9
3,Integer Programming,IP,Objective and constraints are linear, but variables must take integer values.,NP-hard,Knapsack problem with whole items,8
4,Mixed-Integer Linear Programming,MILP,Combines LP with some variables restricted to integers.,NP-hard,Production planning with on/off machines,8
5,Convex Optimization,CO,Minimizing convex objective over convex feasible set; includes LP, QP, and others.,Polynomial time (under conditions),Portfolio optimization with risk constraints,7
6,Quadratic Programming,QP,Objective is quadratic; constraints are linear.,Polynomial time (if convex),Mean-variance portfolio optimization,7
7,Dynamic Programming,DP,Optimization over time via recursive substructure and optimal substructure.,Pseudo-polynomial or exponential,Shortest path in a staged network,6
8,Combinatorial Optimization,COpt,Discrete feasible set; seeks optimal object among finite/countable set.,Often NP-hard,Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP),6
9,Stochastic Programming,SP,Objective or constraints involve random variables; seeks robust or expected performance.,Varies (scenario-based),Supply chain under demand uncertainty,5
10,Robust Optimization,RO,Objective optimized against worst-case uncertainty in parameters.,Often tractable via reformulation,Portfolio immune to market shocks,4
11,Multi-objective Optimization,MOO,Optimizes multiple conflicting objectives simultaneously.,Heuristics or scalarization,Pareto front in engineering design,4
12,Global Optimization,GO,Seeks global optimum in presence of multiple local optima.,Computationally intensive,Protein folding,3
13,Geometric Programming,GP,Special form involving posynomials; transformed into convex problem.,Efficient after transformation,Circuit design with power constraints,3
14,Network Optimization,NO,Problems modeled on graphs/networks (flows, paths, cuts).,Polynomial time (many cases),Minimum cost flow in transportation,3
15,Quadratic Constrained Quadratic Programming,QCQP,Both objective and constraints are quadratic.,NP-hard if non-convex,Radar beamforming,2
16,Second-Order Cone Programming,SOCP,Constraints include second-order (Lorentz) cones.,Polynomial time,Robust least squares,2
17,Semidefinite Programming,SDP,Optimization over positive semidefinite matrices; generalizes LP and SOCP.,Polynomial time (interior point),Max-Cut approximation via relaxation,2
18,Constraint Programming,CP,Focuses on feasibility using logical constraints; often combinatorial.,Heuristics and search,Scheduling with complex rules,2
19,Nonlinear Integer Programming,NLIP,Combines nonlinearity and integrality; highly complex.,NP-hard,Chemical process design with discrete choices,1
20,Bilevel Programming,BLP,Two-level optimization: upper level constrains lower-level problem.,Computationally difficult,Defender-attacker network problem,1
```

731a1da0-0ec1-4eca-bc5d-7b21ee400c3f.content:
Consider software-development using SCRUM as agile method.
What are the typical steps and phases of a SCRUM project? Create a CSV code-block (file) containing all smaller steps/phases from initial project planning, the development cycle, reviews all the until and past the release and CI/CD. 
Create a CSV code-block (file) with header "ID, Step, Description, Interval, Result" and provide the contents in chat.

content_list.content:
```csv
ID,Step,Description,Interval,Result
1,Project Vision & Goal Definition,Define the high-level purpose, objectives, and stakeholders of the project.,One-time (initial),Project vision document, stakeholder alignment
2,Product Backlog Creation,Curate a prioritized list of features, user stories, and requirements.,One-time (initial),Initial product backlog
3,Backlog Refinement (Grooming),Review and refine backlog items: clarify, estimate, and prioritize with the team.,Ongoing (weekly),Updated, detailed, and prioritized backlog
4,Sprint Planning,Team selects backlog items for the upcoming sprint and creates a sprint goal and plan.,Every sprint (2–4 weeks),Sprint backlog, sprint goal
5,Daily Scrum (Stand-up),15-minute daily meeting for team members to sync on progress and blockers.,Daily (Mon-Fri),Team alignment, quick issue detection
6,Sprint Development,Develop, test, and integrate selected backlog items into a potentially shippable increment.,Every sprint (2–4 weeks),Working software increment
7,Continuous Integration (CI),Automatically build and test code changes on every commit.,Continuous,Early bug detection, stable codebase
8,Code Review & Pair Programming,Peer review of code or collaborative coding to ensure quality and knowledge sharing.,As needed / continuous,Higher code quality, shared ownership
9,Sprint Review,Demo the completed increment to stakeholders and gather feedback.,End of each sprint,Stakeholder feedback, validated increment
10,Sprint Retrospective,Team reflects on the sprint process and identifies improvements.,End of each sprint,Actionable process improvements
11,Release Planning,Decide when and what increments will be released to production.,Periodic (every few sprints),Release roadmap and target dates
12,User Acceptance Testing (UAT),End users validate features in a staging environment before release.,Before major release,Approved features for deployment
13,Deployment / Release,Release the software increment to production using automated or manual processes.,As per release plan,Live product update
14,Continuous Delivery / Deployment (CD),Automated pipeline to deploy every change that passes tests to production (CD) or make it production-ready (Continuous Delivery).,Continuous,Quick, reliable releases
15,Post-Release Review / Retrospective,Assess the success of the release, performance, and lessons learned.,After major release,Insights for future improvements
16,Monitoring & Feedback Loop,Monitor system performance and collect user feedback in production.,Continuous,Operational insights, new backlog items
17,Backlog Update with Feedback,Incorporate user feedback, bugs, and feature requests into the product backlog.,Ongoing,Backlog enriched with real-world input
18,Scaling (if applicable),Apply frameworks like SAFe or LeSS if multiple teams are involved.,As needed,Coordinated multi-team delivery
```

1064a325-baad-4a45-9f1b-fd278520db12.content:
In context of a software-development team using scrum, describe what typical factors and forms exist towards the creation of cognitive pressure and stress development.
Create a CSV code-block (file) with header "ID, Name, Description, AffectedEntities, Influence"" where Influences ranges vom 10 (high influence) to 1 (very little influence)" and provide the contents in chat.

content_list.content:
```csv
ID,Name,Description,AffectedEntities,Influence
1,Unrealistic Sprint Goals,Sprints planned with excessive workload or unclear objectives, leading to burnout and fatigue.,Development Team, Scrum Master, Product Owner,10
2,Poorly Defined Requirements,Vague user stories or missing acceptance criteria cause confusion and rework.,Development Team, Product Owner,9
3,Constant Scope Changes,Frequent changes to backlog items or sprint goals disrupt focus and planning.,Entire Scrum Team,9
4,Inadequate Backlog Refinement,Insufficient time spent grooming the backlog results in unprepared stories and mid-sprint surprises.,Development Team, Product Owner,8
5,Interruptions and Context Switching,Team members pulled into unplanned tasks, meetings, or support duties during sprints.,Development Team,8
6,Lack of Psychological Safety,Team members fear speaking up about blockers, mistakes, or concerns in retrospectives or dailies.,Entire Scrum Team,8
7,Ineffective Daily Stand-ups,Meetings become status reports to management instead of team synchronization, increasing pressure.,Development Team, Scrum Master,7
8,Insufficient Autonomy,Team lacks decision-making power over technical or process choices, reducing motivation.,Development Team,7
9,Unresolved Technical Debt,Accumulated poor code quality or outdated systems slow progress and increase frustration.,Development Team,8
10,Inadequate Tooling or CI/CD,Slow builds, flaky tests, or poor development environments waste time and increase stress.,Development Team, DevOps,7
11,Overlapping Sprints or No Buffer Time,Immediate start of new sprints without downtime prevents recovery and reflection.,Development Team, Scrum Master,6
12,Remote Work Challenges,Time zone differences, poor communication tools, or isolation impact collaboration and increase fatigue.,Entire Scrum Team,6
13,Role Ambiguity,Unclear responsibilities between Product Owner, Scrum Master, and team lead to conflict and overwork.,Product Owner, Scrum Master,6
14,High Stakeholder Pressure,External stakeholders demand fast delivery with little tolerance for delays or changes.,Entire Scrum Team, Product Owner,9
15,Ineffective Sprint Retrospectives,Retrospectives lack follow-up actions or are ignored, leading to repeated stressors.,Entire Scrum Team, Scrum Master,7
16,Unbalanced Team Composition,Skill gaps or uneven workload distribution cause some members to carry excessive burden.,Development Team,5
17,Blame Culture,Focus on fault-finding instead of problem-solving discourages transparency and increases anxiety.,Entire Scrum Team,8
18,Understaffing or High Turnover,Too few people or frequent changes in team members increase workload and onboarding pressure.,Development Team, Scrum Master,9
19,Misuse of Velocity,Velocities used as performance metrics rather than planning tools creates pressure to overcommit.,Development Team, Product Owner,8
20,Lack of Recognition or Feedback,Team effort goes unnoticed, reducing motivation and increasing emotional fatigue.,Entire Scrum Team,6
```

Based on Entities.csv and Relationships.csv - Proceed and Create 3 individual CSV code-blocks (alternative: files) in chat named: Goals.csv + Conditions.csv + DecisionVariables.csv
Goals.csv must have the following header: "ID,Name,Description,IsSum,GoalType,EntityName,EntityAttribute,CriteriaType,Weight"
Conditions.csv must have the following header: "ID,Name,Description,IsSum,GoalType,EntityName,EntityAttribute,CriteriaType,Weight"
DecisionVariables.csv must have the following header: "ID,Name,Description,DataType,Domain,MinValue,MaxValue"

The following conventions must be applied:
ID starts with a letter G(oals), C(onditions), D(ecision)V(ariables) and a number follows, starting at 0, 1, 2, ....
Name is written snake_case
Names for Goals must begin with "maximize_" or "minimize_"
IsSum is a boolean { True, False }
GoalType is one of { "min", "max" }
EntityName is always only 1 entry from the "Name" of Entities.csv
EntityAttribute is one of the values in the "Attribute0" to "Attribute8" of the targeted Entity in Entities.csv
CriteriaType is a number { 2 = Must-Match, 1 = May-Match, 0 = Cannot-Match }
Domain can represent set of values like "{0,1}"
MinValue is the smallest value that can be set
MaxValue is the highest value that can be set
Weight is a mulptlier
Created 10 to 15 entries in each of these files.

The items of each category are itemized between \begin and \end.
Goals and Conditions show both their IDs, Names and the logical and mathematical representation

```latex
\documentclass[12pt]{article}
\usepackage{amsmath, amssymb, graphicx, hyperref, enumitem}
\usepackage[letterpaper, margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{tocloft}
\usepackage{titlesec}

\title{Optimization Model for SCRUM-Based Software Development}
\author{AI Modeling Assistant}
\date{\today}

\renewcommand{\cftsecleader}{\cftdotfill{\cftdotsep}} % Add dots in TOC

\titleformat{\section}{\large\bfseries}{\thesection}{1em}{}
\titleformat{\subsection}{\normalsize\bfseries}{\thesubsection}{1em}{}

\begin{document}

\maketitle

\tableofcontents
\newpage

\section{1. Sets (Entities)}
\begin{itemize}
    \item $\mathcal{P}$: Set of Projects (Entity: Project)
    \item $\mathcal{T}$: Set of Teams (Entity: Team)
    \item $\mathcal{W}$: Set of Workers (Entity: Worker)
    \item $\mathcal{F}$: Set of Features (Entity: Feature)
    \item $\mathcal{S}$: Set of Skills (Entity: Skill)
    \item $\mathcal{R}$: Set of Roles (Entity: Role)
    \item $\mathcal{PO}$: Set of Product Owners (Entity: ProductOwner)
    \item $\mathcal{SM}$: Set of Scrum Masters (Entity: ScrumMaster)
    \item $\mathcal{PB}$: Set of Product Backlogs (Entity: ProductBacklog)
    \item $\mathcal{SP}$: Set of Sprints (Entity: Sprint)
    \item $\mathcal{SPP}$: Set of Sprint Plannings (Entity: SprintPlanning)
    \item $\mathcal{DS}$: Set of Daily Scrums (Entity: DailyScrum)
    \item $\mathcal{SR}$: Set of Sprint Reviews (Entity: SprintReview)
    \item $\mathcal{SRE}$: Set of Sprint Retrospectives (Entity: SprintRetrospective)
    \item $\mathcal{SBL}$: Set of Sprint Backlogs (Entity: SprintBacklog)
    \item $\mathcal{SG}$: Set of Sprint Goals (Entity: SprintGoal)
    \item $\mathcal{E}$: Set of Epics (Entity: Epic)
    \item $\mathcal{US}$: Set of User Stories (Entity: UserStory)
    \item $\mathcal{TSK}$: Set of Tasks (Entity: Task)
    \item $\mathcal{DEV}$: Set of Development Snapshots (Entity: DevelopmentSnapshot)
    \item $\mathcal{BL}$: Set of Blockers (Entity: Blocker)
    \item $\mathcal{SH}$: Set of Stakeholders (Entity: Stakeholder)
    \item $\mathcal{VEL}$: Set of Velocity Records (Entity: Velocity)
    \item $\mathcal{REP}$: Set of Release Plans (Entity: ReleasePlan)
    \item $\mathcal{RM}$: Set of Roadmaps (Entity: Roadmap)
    \item $\mathcal{SCB}$: Set of Scrum Boards (Entity: ScrumBoard)
    \item $\mathcal{FED}$: Set of Feature Documentations (Entity: FeatureDocumentation)
\end{itemize}

\section{2. Indices}
\begin{itemize}
    \item $p \in \mathcal{P}$: Index for projects
    \item $t \in \mathcal{T}$: Index for teams
    \item $w \in \mathcal{W}$: Index for workers
    \item $f \in \mathcal{F}$: Index for features
    \item $s \in \mathcal{S}$: Index for skills
    \item $r \in \mathcal{R}$: Index for roles
    \item $po \in \mathcal{PO}$: Index for product owners
    \item $sm \in \mathcal{SM}$: Index for scrum masters
    \item $pb \in \mathcal{PB}$: Index for product backlogs
    \item $sp \in \mathcal{SP}$: Index for sprints
    \item $sbl \in \mathcal{SBL}$: Index for sprint backlogs
    \item $us \in \mathcal{US}$: Index for user stories
    \item $tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}$: Index for tasks
    \item $bl \in \mathcal{BL}$: Index for blockers
    \item $sh \in \mathcal{SH}$: Index for stakeholders
    \item $rep \in \mathcal{REP}$: Index for release plans
    \item $vel \in \mathcal{VEL}$: Index for velocity records
\end{itemize}

\section{3. Goals}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[G0] \texttt{maximize\_completed\_story\_points}: Maximize total completed story points.
    \[
    \max \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} x_{us} \cdot \text{story\_points}(us)
    \]
    where $x_{us} = 1$ if user story $us$ is completed.

    \item[G1] \texttt{maximize\_team\_velocity}: Maximize average team velocity.
    \[
    \max \text{avg\_story\_points}(vel) \quad \text{for } vel \in \mathcal{VEL}
    \]

    \item[G2] \texttt{minimize\_open\_blockers}: Minimize unresolved blockers.
    \[
    \min \sum_{bl \in \mathcal{BL}} (1 - \mathbb{I}[\text{resolved\_on}(bl) > 0])
    \]

    \item[G3] \texttt{maximize\_requirement\_clarity}: Maximize clarity via presence of acceptance criteria.
    \[
    \max \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} \mathbb{I}[\text{acceptance\_criteria}(us) \neq \emptyset]
    \]

    \item[G4] \texttt{maximize\_feature\_delivery\_rate}: Maximize delivered features.
    \[
    \max \sum_{f \in \mathcal{F}} \mathbb{I}[\text{status}(f) = \texttt{"Done"}]
    \]

    \item[G5] \texttt{minimize\_sprint\_goal\_failures}: Minimize failed sprint goals.
    \[
    \min \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \mathbb{I}[\text{achievement\_of\_goal}(sp) = \texttt{"Failed"}]
    \]

    \item[G6] \texttt{maximize\_stakeholder\_participation}: Maximize stakeholder attendance.
    \[
    \max \sum_{sr \in \mathcal{SR}} \text{attendees\_count}(sr)
    \]

    \item[G7] \texttt{minimize\_task\_effort\_deviation}: Minimize estimated vs. actual effort deviation.
    \[
    \min \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \left| \text{actual\_effort}(tsk) - \text{effort}(tsk) \right|
    \]
    (Assume actual effort is observable or estimated post-hoc.)

    \item[G8] \texttt{maximize\_documentation\_coverage}: Maximize documented features.
    \[
    \max \sum_{fed \in \mathcal{FED}} \mathbb{I}[\text{linked\_requirements}(fed) \neq \emptyset]
    \]

    \item[G9] \texttt{maximize\_team\_availability}: Maximize available worker capacity.
    \[
    \max \sum_{w \in \mathcal{W}} \text{availability}(w)
    \]

    \item[G10] \texttt{minimize\_technical\_debt\_accumulation}: Minimize technical debt tasks.
    \[
    \min \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \mathbb{I}[\text{type}(tsk) = \texttt{"technical\_debt"}]
    \]

    \item[G11] \texttt{maximize\_backlog\_refinement\_rate}: Maximize refined backlog entries.
    \[
    \max \text{number\_of\_entries}(pb) \quad \text{for } pb \in \mathcal{PB}
    \]

    \item[G12] \texttt{minimize\_release\_delay}: Minimize release delays.
    \[
    \min \sum_{rep \in \mathcal{REP}} \max(0, \text{actual\_release\_date}(rep) - \text{planned\_date}(rep))
    \]

    \item[G13] \texttt{maximize\_cross\_functionality}: Maximize skill diversity per team.
    \[
    \max \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} |\{ s \in \mathcal{S} \mid \exists w \in t : \text{has\_skill}(w,s) \}|
    \]

    \item[G14] \texttt{minimize\_sprint\_scope\_changes}: Minimize mid-sprint changes.
    \[
    \min \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \text{count\_of\_mid\_sprint\_additions}(sp)
    \]
\end{itemize}

\section{4. Conditions}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[C0] \texttt{assign_worker_to_team}: Each worker assigned to at most one team.
    \[
    \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} y_{w,t} \leq 1 \quad \forall w \in \mathcal{W}
    \]
    where $y_{w,t} \in \{0,1\}$ indicates assignment.

    \item[C1] \texttt{task_belongs_to_user_story}: Each task belongs to exactly one user story.
    \[
    \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} z_{tsk,us} = 1 \quad \forall tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}
    \]
    where $z_{tsk,us} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C2] \texttt{user_story_in_sprint_backlog}: A user story can only be in one sprint backlog.
    \[
    \sum_{sbl \in \mathcal{SBL}} a_{us,sbl} \leq 1 \quad \forall us \in \mathcal{US}
    \]
    where $a_{us,sbl} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C3] \texttt{sprint_duration_constraint}: Each sprint lasts between 1 and 4 weeks.
    \[
    7 \leq \text{end\_date}(sp) - \text{start\_date}(sp) \leq 28 \quad \forall sp \in \mathcal{SP}
    \]

    \item[C4] \texttt{worker_skill_requirement}: Workers assigned to tasks must have required skills.
    \[
    y_{w,t} \cdot \text{has\_skill}(w,s) \geq \text{required\_skill}(tsk,s) \cdot x_{tsk}
    \]
    for relevant $w, tsk, s$.

    \item[C5] \texttt{scrum_events_occurrence}: Each sprint must have exactly one planning, review, and retrospective.
    \[
    \exists spp \in \mathcal{SPP}, sr \in \mathcal{SR}, sre \in \mathcal{SRE} : \text{linked to } sp
    \]

    \item[C6] \texttt{product_owner_manages_backlog}: Each product backlog is managed by one PO.
    \[
    \sum_{po \in \mathcal{PO}} b_{pb,po} = 1 \quad \forall pb \in \mathcal{PB}
    \]
    where $b_{pb,po} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C7] \texttt{team_has_scrum_master}: Each team has exactly one Scrum Master.
    \[
    \sum_{sm \in \mathcal{SM}} c_{t,sm} = 1 \quad \forall t \in \mathcal{T}
    \]

    \item[C8] \texttt{task_effort_within_capacity}: Total assigned task effort $\leq$ worker capacity.
    \[
    \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \text{effort}(tsk) \cdot d_{w,tsk} \leq \text{availability}(w) \quad \forall w \in \mathcal{W}
    \]
    where $d_{w,tsk} \in \{0,1\}$ if worker $w$ does task $tsk$.

    \item[C9] \texttt{epic_contains_user_stories}: Each epic must contain at least one user story.
    \[
    \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} e_{e,us} \geq 1 \quad \forall e \in \mathcal{E}
    \]
    where $e_{e,us} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C10] \texttt{release_plan_includes_features}: Release plan must include only valid features.
    \[
    \text{included\_features}(rep) \subseteq \mathcal{F} \quad \forall rep \in \mathcal{REP}
    \]

    \item[C11] \texttt{velocity_based_on_completed_points}: Velocity must reflect actual completed story points.
    \[
    \text{avg\_story\_points}(vel) = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{SP}|} \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} \text{story\_points}(us) \cdot x_{us,sp}
    \]

    \item[C12] \texttt{daily_scrum_frequency}: At least one Daily Scrum per working day during sprint.
    \[
    |\{ ds \in \mathcal{DS} \mid \text{date}(ds) \in [\text{start\_date}(sp), \text{end\_date}(sp)] \}| \geq \text{working\_days}(sp)
    \]

    \item[C13] \texttt{blocker_resolution_time}: Blockers must be resolved within 3 days.
    \[
    \text{resolved\_on}(bl) - \text{detected\_on}(bl) \leq 3 \quad \forall bl \in \mathcal{BL}
    \]

    \item[C14] \texttt{documentation_must_exist}: Every completed feature must have documentation.
    \[
    \forall f \in \mathcal{F}, \text{if status}(f) = \texttt{"Done"}, \exists fed \in \mathcal{FED} : \text{linked\_requirements}(fed) = f
    \]
\end{itemize}

\section{5. DecisionVariables}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[DV0] $x_{us}$: Completion status of user story $us$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Binary indicator if user story is completed
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV1] $y_{w,t}$: Worker-team assignment
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether worker $w$ is assigned to team $t$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV2] $z_{tsk,us}$: Task-to-user-story mapping
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether task $tsk$ belongs to user story $us$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV3] $a_{us,sbl}$: User story in sprint backlog
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Assignment of user story to sprint backlog
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV4] $b_{pb,po}$: Product Backlog ownership
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether PO manages a given product backlog
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV5] $c_{t,sm}$: Team-Scrum Master assignment
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Assignment of Scrum Master to team
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV6] $d_{w,tsk}$: Task assignment to worker
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether worker $w$ performs task $tsk$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV7] $e_{e,us}$: Epic-user story membership
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether user story belongs to an epic
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV8] $v_{sp}$: Actual velocity in sprint $sp$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Measured velocity (story points completed)
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 100
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV9] $f_{rep}$: Release delay in days
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Number of days a release is delayed
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 90
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV10] $g_{bl}$: Blocker resolution time
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Duration (days) a blocker remains unresolved
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 10
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV11] $h_{tsk}$: Actual effort spent on task
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Realized effort (e.g., hours) for task
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 40
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV12] $k_{w}$: Availability level of worker $w$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Weekly available hours
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, 40]$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 40
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV13] $m_{f}$: Documentation status of feature
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether documentation exists for feature
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV14] $n_{sp}$: Number of mid-sprint changes
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Count of scope changes during sprint
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 20
    \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\end{document}
```

13d43ef6-43ef-444a-a818-a4ae4a42a2e6.content:
Transform all of the provided and generated CSV data (Entities, Attributes, Relations, Goals, Conditions, DecisionVariables) into a graph using the Mermaid.js Live Editor graph TD syntax.
Connect...
- Entities with their Attributes and place the Attributes around the Entities they belong to. (can exist multiple times in the graph to make lines less short)
- Entities with their Relations
- Goals with the Entity/Attributes
- Conditions with the Entity/Attributes
- DecisionVariables with their relevant Entities

Colorize...
- Entities in blue
- Attributes in white
- Relations in orange
- Goals in green
- Conditions in red
- Decision Variables in purple

content_list.content:
Here's a **Mermaid.js `graph TD`** representation that integrates **all** the provided and generated 

- Entities (blue)
- Attributes (white)
- Relationships (orange)
- Goals (green)
- Conditions (red)
- Decision Variables (purple)

The graph connects:
- Entities ↔ Attributes
- Entities ↔ Relations
- Goals ↔ Entity + Attribute
- Conditions ↔ Entity + Attribute
- DecisionVariables ↔ Entities

> ✅ This code is designed to be used in the **[Mermaid Live Editor](https://mermaid.live/edit)**. Due to complexity, it’s optimized for readability and structure. For best layout, use `graph TD` with `direction TB` or `direction LR`.

---

```mermaid
graph TD
    %% =============== STYLING ===============
    classDef entity fill:#1f77b4,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef attribute fill:#ffffff,stroke:#333,stroke-width:1px,color:#333;
    classDef relation fill:#ff8c00,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef goal fill:#2ca02c,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef condition fill:#d62728,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef decisionVar fill:#9467bd,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;

    %% =============== ENTITIES ===============
    E0[Project]:::entity
    E1[Team]:::entity
    E2[Worker]:::entity
    E3[Feature]:::entity
    E4[Skill]:::entity
    E5[Role]:::entity
    E6[ProductOwner]:::entity
    E7[ScrumMaster]:::entity
    E8[ProductBacklog]:::entity
    E9[Sprint]:::entity
    E10[SprintPlanning]:::entity
    E11[DailyScrum]:::entity
    E12[SprintReview]:::entity
    E13[SprintRetrospective]:::entity
    E14[SprintBacklog]:::entity
    E15[SprintGoal]:::entity
    E16[Epic]:::entity
    E17[UserStory]:::entity
    E18[Task]:::entity
    E19[DevelopmentSnapshot]:::entity
    E20[Blocker]:::entity
    E21[Stakeholder]:::entity
    E22[Velocity]:::entity
    E23[ReleasePlan]:::entity
    E24[Roadmap]:::entity
    E25[ScrumBoard]:::entity
    E26[FeatureDocumentation]:::entity

    %% =============== ATTRIBUTES (connected to entities) ===============
    %% Project
    E0 --> id_p
    E0 --> name_p
    E0 --> project_start
    E0 --> project_end
    E0 --> description_p
    E0 --> budget
    E0 --> status_p
    E0 --> target_audience
    E0 --> priority_p

    %% Team
    E1 --> id_t
    E1 --> name_t
    E1 --> team_size
    E1 --> team_start
    E1 --> team_status
    E1 --> location
    E1 --> team_type

    %% Worker
    E2 --> id_w
    E2 --> name_w
    E2 --> first_name
    E2 --> email_w
    E2 --> start_date_w

    E2 --> availability_w

    %% Feature

    E3 --> estimated_effort_f

    %% Skill

    %% Role

    %% ProductOwner

    %% ScrumMaster

    %% ProductBacklog

    E8 --> number_of_entries_pb
    E8 --> status_pb

    %% Sprint
    E9 --> id_sp
    E9 --> sprint_number
    E9 --> start_date_sp
    E9 --> end_date_sp
    E9 --> status_sp
    E9 --> achievement_of_goal_sp

    %% SprintPlanning
    E10 --> id_spp
    E10 --> date_spp
    E10 --> duration_min_spp
    E10 --> moderation_spp
    E10 --> outcome_documentation_spp

    %% DailyScrum
    E11 --> id_ds
    E11 --> date_ds
    E11 --> time_ds
    E11 --> duration_ds
    E11 --> moderation_ds

    %% SprintReview
    E12 --> id_sr
    E12 --> date_sr
    E12 --> duration_sr
    E12 --> feedback_documentation_sr
    E12 --> attendees_count_sr

    %% SprintRetrospective
    E13 --> id_sre
    E13 --> date_sre
    E13 --> duration_sre
    E13 --> improvement_actions_sre
    E13 --> team_satisfaction_sre
    E13 --> moderation_sre

    %% SprintBacklog
    E14 --> id_sbl

    E14 --> status_sbl
    E14 --> total_effort_sbl

    %% SprintGoal
    E15 --> id_sg

    E15 --> achievement_status_sg
    E15 --> benefit_sg

    %% Epic
    E16 --> id_e
    E16 --> title_e
    E16 --> description_e
    E16 --> priority_e
    E16 --> status_e
    E16 --> estimated_effort_e

    %% UserStory
    E17 --> id_us
    E17 --> title_us
    E17 --> description_us
    E17 --> acceptance_criteria_us
    E17 --> priority_us
    E17 --> story_points_us
    E17 --> status_us

    %% Task
    E18 --> id_tsk
    E18 --> title_tsk
    E18 --> description_tsk

    %% DevelopmentSnapshot
    E19 --> id_dev

    %% Blocker
    E20 --> id_bl
    E20 --> title_bl
    E20 --> description_bl

    E20 --> status_bl

    E20 --> resolved_on_bl

    %% Stakeholder
    E21 --> id_sh
    E21 --> name_sh
    E21 --> organization_sh
    E21 --> role_sh
    E21 --> email_sh
    E21 --> area_of_interest_sh
    E21 --> influence_level_sh
    E21 --> relevance_to_feature_sh

    %% Velocity
    E22 --> id_vel
    E22 --> number_of_sprints_used_vel
    E22 --> avg_story_points_vel
    E22 --> max_velocity_vel
    E22 --> min_velocity_vel
    E22 --> trend_vel

    %% ReleasePlan
    E23 --> id_rep
    E23 --> version_rep
    E23 --> planned_date_rep
    E23 --> included_features_rep
    E23 --> status_rep

    %% Roadmap
    E24 --> id_rm
    E24 --> start_date_rm
    E24 --> end_date_rm
    E24 --> milestones_rm
    E24 --> objectives_rm
    E24 --> versions_rm

    %% ScrumBoard
    E25 --> id_scb
    E25 --> board_type_scb
    E25 --> columns_todo_done_scb
    E25 --> number_of_cards_scb
    E25 --> last_updated_scb

    %% FeatureDocumentation
    E26 --> id_fed
    E26 --> title_fed
    E26 --> description_fed
    E26 --> creation_date_fed
    E26 --> change_log_fed
    E26 --> linked_requirements_fed
    E26 --> author_fed

    %% =============== RELATIONS (orange) ===============
    R1[is_assigned_to_project]:::relation
    R2[belongs_to_team]:::relation
    R3[has_skill]:::relation
    R4[takes_on_role]:::relation
    R5[manages_backlog]:::relation
    R6[is_supported_by]:::relation
    R7[contains_feature]:::relation
    R8[contains_epic]:::relation
    R9[contains_user_story]:::relation
    R10[consists_of_tasks]:::relation
    R11[is_in_sprint_backlog]:::relation
    R12[belongs_to_sprint]:::relation
    R13[pursues_goal]:::relation
    R14[contains_tasks]:::relation
    R15[documents_feature]:::relation
    R16[is_blocked_by]:::relation
    R17[participates_in]:::relation
    R18[moderates_retrospective]:::relation
    R19[refers_to_team]:::relation
    R20[plans_release]:::relation
    R21[is_part_of_roadmap]:::relation
    R22[generates_snapshot]:::relation

    %% Connect relations to entities
    R1 --> E1 & E0
    R2 --> E2 & E1
    R3 --> E2 & E4
    R4 --> E2 & E5
    R5 --> E6 & E8
    R6 --> E1 & E7
    R7 --> E8 & E3
    R8 --> E8 & E16
    R9 --> E16 & E17
    R10 --> E17 & E18
    R11 --> E17 & E14
    R12 --> E14 & E9
    R13 --> E9 & E15
    R14 --> E25 & E18
    R15 --> E26 & E3
    R16 --> E18 & E20
    R17 --> E21 & E12
    R18 --> E7 & E13
    R19 --> E22 & E1
    R20 --> E23 & E3
    R21 --> E23 & E24
    R22 --> E9 & E19

    %% =============== GOALS (green) ===============
    G0[maximize_completed_story_points]:::goal
    G1[maximize_team_velocity]:::goal
    G2[minimize_open_blockers]:::goal
    G3[maximize_requirement_clarity]:::goal
    G4[maximize_feature_delivery_rate]:::goal
    G5[minimize_sprint_goal_failures]:::goal
    G6[maximize_stakeholder_participation]:::goal
    G7[minimize_task_effort_deviation]:::goal
    G8[maximize_documentation_coverage]:::goal
    G9[maximize_team_availability]:::goal
    G10[minimize_technical_debt_accumulation]:::goal
    G11[maximize_backlog_refinement_rate]:::goal
    G12[minimize_release_delay]:::goal
    G13[maximize_cross_functionality]:::goal
    G14[minimize_sprint_scope_changes]:::goal

    %% Connect Goals to Entity + Attribute
    G0 --> E17 --> story_points_us
    G1 --> E22 --> avg_story_points_vel
    G2 --> E20 --> resolved_on_bl
    G3 --> E17 --> acceptance_criteria_us
    G4 --> E3 --> status_f
    G5 --> E9 --> achievement_of_goal_sp
    G6 --> E12 --> attendees_count_sr
    G7 --> E18 --> effort_tsk
    G8 --> E26 --> linked_requirements_fed
    G9 --> E2 --> availability_w
    G10 --> E18 --> type_tsk
    G11 --> E8 --> number_of_entries_pb

    %% =============== CONDITIONS (red) ===============
    C0[assign_worker_to_team]:::condition
    C1[task_belongs_to_user_story]:::condition
    C2[user_story_in_sprint_backlog]:::condition
    C3[sprint_duration_constraint]:::condition
    C4[worker_skill_requirement]:::condition
    C5[scrum_events_occurrence]:::condition
    C6[product_owner_manages_backlog]:::condition

    C12[daily_scrum_frequency]:::condition
    C13[blocker_resolution_time]:::condition
    C14[documentation_must_exist]:::condition

    %% Connect Conditions to Entity + Attribute
    C0 --> E2 & E1
    C1 --> E18 & E17
    C2 --> E17 & E14
    C3 --> E9 --> start_date_sp & end_date_sp
    C4 --> E2 & E4 & E18
    C5 --> E9 & E10 & E11 & E12 & E13
    C6 --> E8 & E6
    C7 --> E1 & E7

    C9 --> E16 & E17
    C10 --> E23 & E3
```

messages.content:
What do you know about optimization problems? 
Create a table storing the different categories, types, forms, their names, descriptions and order it from most appearances (10) to less appearances (1). 
Provide the result as CSV code-block (file) with header "Rank,Name,Abbreviation,Description,Solvability,Example,Appearances"

content_list.content:
```csv
Rank,Name,Abbreviation,Description,Solvability,Example,Appearances
1,Linear Programming,LP,Optimization of a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.,Polynomial time (e.g., Simplex, Interior Point),Maximize profit given resource constraints,10
2,Nonlinear Programming,NLP,Objective function or constraints are nonlinear; generalization of LP.,Varies (local/global solvers),Minimize energy in a physical system,9
3,Integer Programming,IP,Objective and constraints are linear, but variables must take integer values.,NP-hard,Knapsack problem with whole items,8
4,Mixed-Integer Linear Programming,MILP,Combines LP with some variables restricted to integers.,NP-hard,Production planning with on/off machines,8
5,Convex Optimization,CO,Minimizing convex objective over convex feasible set; includes LP, QP, and others.,Polynomial time (under conditions),Portfolio optimization with risk constraints,7
6,Quadratic Programming,QP,Objective is quadratic; constraints are linear.,Polynomial time (if convex),Mean-variance portfolio optimization,7
7,Dynamic Programming,DP,Optimization over time via recursive substructure and optimal substructure.,Pseudo-polynomial or exponential,Shortest path in a staged network,6
8,Combinatorial Optimization,COpt,Discrete feasible set; seeks optimal object among finite/countable set.,Often NP-hard,Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP),6
9,Stochastic Programming,SP,Objective or constraints involve random variables; seeks robust or expected performance.,Varies (scenario-based),Supply chain under demand uncertainty,5
10,Robust Optimization,RO,Objective optimized against worst-case uncertainty in parameters.,Often tractable via reformulation,Portfolio immune to market shocks,4
11,Multi-objective Optimization,MOO,Optimizes multiple conflicting objectives simultaneously.,Heuristics or scalarization,Pareto front in engineering design,4
12,Global Optimization,GO,Seeks global optimum in presence of multiple local optima.,Computationally intensive,Protein folding,3
13,Geometric Programming,GP,Special form involving posynomials; transformed into convex problem.,Efficient after transformation,Circuit design with power constraints,3
14,Network Optimization,NO,Problems modeled on graphs/networks (flows, paths, cuts).,Polynomial time (many cases),Minimum cost flow in transportation,3
15,Quadratic Constrained Quadratic Programming,QCQP,Both objective and constraints are quadratic.,NP-hard if non-convex,Radar beamforming,2
16,Second-Order Cone Programming,SOCP,Constraints include second-order (Lorentz) cones.,Polynomial time,Robust least squares,2
17,Semidefinite Programming,SDP,Optimization over positive semidefinite matrices; generalizes LP and SOCP.,Polynomial time (interior point),Max-Cut approximation via relaxation,2
18,Constraint Programming,CP,Focuses on feasibility using logical constraints; often combinatorial.,Heuristics and search,Scheduling with complex rules,2
19,Nonlinear Integer Programming,NLIP,Combines nonlinearity and integrality; highly complex.,NP-hard,Chemical process design with discrete choices,1
20,Bilevel Programming,BLP,Two-level optimization: upper level constrains lower-level problem.,Computationally difficult,Defender-attacker network problem,1
```

messages.content:
Consider software-development using SCRUM as agile method.
What are the typical steps and phases of a SCRUM project? Create a CSV code-block (file) containing all smaller steps/phases from initial project planning, the development cycle, reviews all the until and past the release and CI/CD. 
Create a CSV code-block (file) with header "ID, Step, Description, Interval, Result" and provide the contents in chat.

content_list.content:
```csv
ID,Step,Description,Interval,Result
1,Project Vision & Goal Definition,Define the high-level purpose, objectives, and stakeholders of the project.,One-time (initial),Project vision document, stakeholder alignment
2,Product Backlog Creation,Curate a prioritized list of features, user stories, and requirements.,One-time (initial),Initial product backlog
3,Backlog Refinement (Grooming),Review and refine backlog items: clarify, estimate, and prioritize with the team.,Ongoing (weekly),Updated, detailed, and prioritized backlog
4,Sprint Planning,Team selects backlog items for the upcoming sprint and creates a sprint goal and plan.,Every sprint (2–4 weeks),Sprint backlog, sprint goal
5,Daily Scrum (Stand-up),15-minute daily meeting for team members to sync on progress and blockers.,Daily (Mon-Fri),Team alignment, quick issue detection
6,Sprint Development,Develop, test, and integrate selected backlog items into a potentially shippable increment.,Every sprint (2–4 weeks),Working software increment
7,Continuous Integration (CI),Automatically build and test code changes on every commit.,Continuous,Early bug detection, stable codebase
8,Code Review & Pair Programming,Peer review of code or collaborative coding to ensure quality and knowledge sharing.,As needed / continuous,Higher code quality, shared ownership
9,Sprint Review,Demo the completed increment to stakeholders and gather feedback.,End of each sprint,Stakeholder feedback, validated increment
10,Sprint Retrospective,Team reflects on the sprint process and identifies improvements.,End of each sprint,Actionable process improvements
11,Release Planning,Decide when and what increments will be released to production.,Periodic (every few sprints),Release roadmap and target dates
12,User Acceptance Testing (UAT),End users validate features in a staging environment before release.,Before major release,Approved features for deployment
13,Deployment / Release,Release the software increment to production using automated or manual processes.,As per release plan,Live product update
14,Continuous Delivery / Deployment (CD),Automated pipeline to deploy every change that passes tests to production (CD) or make it production-ready (Continuous Delivery).,Continuous,Quick, reliable releases
15,Post-Release Review / Retrospective,Assess the success of the release, performance, and lessons learned.,After major release,Insights for future improvements
16,Monitoring & Feedback Loop,Monitor system performance and collect user feedback in production.,Continuous,Operational insights, new backlog items
17,Backlog Update with Feedback,Incorporate user feedback, bugs, and feature requests into the product backlog.,Ongoing,Backlog enriched with real-world input
18,Scaling (if applicable),Apply frameworks like SAFe or LeSS if multiple teams are involved.,As needed,Coordinated multi-team delivery
```

In context of SCRUM, analyze how Natural Language Processing can be used to extract, structure and evaluate system requirements and their complexity in the software development process. 
Create a CSV code-block (file) with header "Keyword, Category, Description, RelevantScrumEntities" and provide the contents in chat.

content_list.content:
```csv
Keyword,Category,Description,RelevantScrumEntities
User Story,Requirement Artifact,A natural language description of a feature from the perspective of the end user, often in the form: "As a [role], I want [feature] so that [benefit].",Product Backlog, Sprint Planning, Backlog Refinement
Acceptance Criteria,Requirement Specification,Conditions that a software feature must satisfy to be accepted by stakeholders; typically written in Given-When-Then format.,Product Backlog Item, Sprint Review, Definition of Done
Named Entity Recognition (NER),NLP Technique,Identifies and classifies key information (e.g., user roles, actions, systems) in text to extract structured requirements.,Backlog Refinement, User Story Creation
Part-of-Speech (POS) Tagging,Text Analysis Technique,Tags words in a sentence with their grammatical roles; helps parse user stories and detect completeness.,Backlog Refinement, Requirement Validation
Dependency Parsing,Text Analysis Technique,Analyzes grammatical structure to identify relationships between words; useful for detecting feature dependencies.,Backlog Refinement, Sprint Planning
Sentiment Analysis,Text Analysis Technique,Detects tone and emotion in stakeholder feedback or user reports to prioritize issues or features.,Product Backlog, Sprint Review, Post-Release Review
Complexity Estimation,NLP Application,Uses text features (length, vocabulary, syntax) to predict effort or story points automatically.,Backlog Refinement, Sprint Planning
Text Summarization,Information Extraction,Generates concise summaries from lengthy requirements or meeting notes for backlog clarity.,Product Backlog, Sprint Retrospective
Semantic Similarity,Matching Technique,Measures how similar two user stories are to detect duplication or group related items.,Backlog Refinement, Product Backlog Grooming
Intent Classification,Classification Task,Categorizes user input (e.g., feature request, bug report) into predefined requirement types.,Product Backlog, Backlog Refinement
Natural Language to Formal Specification,Transformation Task,Converts informal user stories into structured models (e.g., UML, use cases) using rule-based or ML methods.,Sprint Planning, Development
Feature Extraction,Information Extraction,Identifies functional and non-functional features from textual requirements.,Product Backlog, Requirement Analysis
Ambiguity Detection,Quality Check,Flags vague terms (e.g., "fast", "user-friendly") in requirements using lexicons or ML.,Backlog Refinement, Definition of Ready
Stakeholder Role Identification,Entity Recognition,Extracts user roles (e.g., admin, customer) from user stories to improve persona modeling.,User Story, Product Backlog
Automated Acceptance Criteria Generation,Generation Task,Generates testable acceptance criteria from user stories using templates or AI.,User Story, Sprint Planning, Testing
Effort Prediction,Estimation Support,Uses NLP-derived metrics (e.g., story length, clarity) to predict development effort or story points.,Backlog Refinement, Sprint Planning
Feedback Mining,Insight Extraction,Extracts actionable insights from user feedback, support tickets, or reviews to inform backlog items.,Product Backlog, Post-Release Review
Multilingual Requirement Processing,Language Support,Translates and normalizes requirements from multiple languages for global teams.,Product Backlog, Backlog Refinement
Traceability Link Generation,Linking Task,Creates links between user stories, code, and tests by analyzing textual similarity.,Product Backlog, Testing, CI/CD
Chatbot for Requirement Elicitation,Interaction Tool,Uses conversational NLP to gather and structure requirements from stakeholders via chat.,Product Backlog Creation, Initial Planning
```

messages.content:
In context of a software-development team using scrum, describe what typical factors and forms exist towards the creation of cognitive pressure and stress development.
Create a CSV code-block (file) with header "ID, Name, Description, AffectedEntities, Influence"" where Influences ranges vom 10 (high influence) to 1 (very little influence)" and provide the contents in chat.

content_list.content:
```csv
ID,Name,Description,AffectedEntities,Influence
1,Unrealistic Sprint Goals,Sprints planned with excessive workload or unclear objectives, leading to burnout and fatigue.,Development Team, Scrum Master, Product Owner,10
2,Poorly Defined Requirements,Vague user stories or missing acceptance criteria cause confusion and rework.,Development Team, Product Owner,9
3,Constant Scope Changes,Frequent changes to backlog items or sprint goals disrupt focus and planning.,Entire Scrum Team,9
4,Inadequate Backlog Refinement,Insufficient time spent grooming the backlog results in unprepared stories and mid-sprint surprises.,Development Team, Product Owner,8
5,Interruptions and Context Switching,Team members pulled into unplanned tasks, meetings, or support duties during sprints.,Development Team,8
6,Lack of Psychological Safety,Team members fear speaking up about blockers, mistakes, or concerns in retrospectives or dailies.,Entire Scrum Team,8
7,Ineffective Daily Stand-ups,Meetings become status reports to management instead of team synchronization, increasing pressure.,Development Team, Scrum Master,7
8,Insufficient Autonomy,Team lacks decision-making power over technical or process choices, reducing motivation.,Development Team,7
9,Unresolved Technical Debt,Accumulated poor code quality or outdated systems slow progress and increase frustration.,Development Team,8
10,Inadequate Tooling or CI/CD,Slow builds, flaky tests, or poor development environments waste time and increase stress.,Development Team, DevOps,7
11,Overlapping Sprints or No Buffer Time,Immediate start of new sprints without downtime prevents recovery and reflection.,Development Team, Scrum Master,6
12,Remote Work Challenges,Time zone differences, poor communication tools, or isolation impact collaboration and increase fatigue.,Entire Scrum Team,6
13,Role Ambiguity,Unclear responsibilities between Product Owner, Scrum Master, and team lead to conflict and overwork.,Product Owner, Scrum Master,6
14,High Stakeholder Pressure,External stakeholders demand fast delivery with little tolerance for delays or changes.,Entire Scrum Team, Product Owner,9
15,Ineffective Sprint Retrospectives,Retrospectives lack follow-up actions or are ignored, leading to repeated stressors.,Entire Scrum Team, Scrum Master,7
16,Unbalanced Team Composition,Skill gaps or uneven workload distribution cause some members to carry excessive burden.,Development Team,5
17,Blame Culture,Focus on fault-finding instead of problem-solving discourages transparency and increases anxiety.,Entire Scrum Team,8
18,Understaffing or High Turnover,Too few people or frequent changes in team members increase workload and onboarding pressure.,Development Team, Scrum Master,9
19,Misuse of Velocity,Velocities used as performance metrics rather than planning tools creates pressure to overcommit.,Development Team, Product Owner,8
20,Lack of Recognition or Feedback,Team effort goes unnoticed, reducing motivation and increasing emotional fatigue.,Entire Scrum Team,6
```

Use ALL of the previously provided and generated CSV data (Entities, Relations, Goals, Conditions, DecisionVariables) and formulate the optimization model mathematically and logically. 
Write it into a code-block for a LaTeX (.tex) file and provide the generated Latex code in chat.
The file consists of a introduction page with Title, Author, Date and Table of Contents.
The actual file contest consists of 5 different \sections labeled "1. Sets (Entities)", "2. Indices", "3. Goals", "4. Conditions", "5. DecisionVariables"
The items of each category are itemized between \begin and \end.
Goals and Conditions show both their IDs, Names and the logical and mathematical representation

content_list.content:
```latex
\documentclass[12pt]{article}
\usepackage{amsmath, amssymb, graphicx, hyperref, enumitem}
\usepackage[letterpaper, margin=1in]{geometry}
\usepackage{tocloft}
\usepackage{titlesec}

\title{Optimization Model for SCRUM-Based Software Development}
\author{AI Modeling Assistant}
\date{\today}

\renewcommand{\cftsecleader}{\cftdotfill{\cftdotsep}} % Add dots in TOC

\titleformat{\section}{\large\bfseries}{\thesection}{1em}{}
\titleformat{\subsection}{\normalsize\bfseries}{\thesubsection}{1em}{}

\begin{document}

\maketitle

\tableofcontents
\newpage

\section{1. Sets (Entities)}
\begin{itemize}
    \item $\mathcal{P}$: Set of Projects (Entity: Project)
    \item $\mathcal{T}$: Set of Teams (Entity: Team)
    \item $\mathcal{W}$: Set of Workers (Entity: Worker)
    \item $\mathcal{F}$: Set of Features (Entity: Feature)
    \item $\mathcal{S}$: Set of Skills (Entity: Skill)
    \item $\mathcal{R}$: Set of Roles (Entity: Role)
    \item $\mathcal{PO}$: Set of Product Owners (Entity: ProductOwner)
    \item $\mathcal{SM}$: Set of Scrum Masters (Entity: ScrumMaster)
    \item $\mathcal{PB}$: Set of Product Backlogs (Entity: ProductBacklog)
    \item $\mathcal{SP}$: Set of Sprints (Entity: Sprint)
    \item $\mathcal{SPP}$: Set of Sprint Plannings (Entity: SprintPlanning)
    \item $\mathcal{DS}$: Set of Daily Scrums (Entity: DailyScrum)
    \item $\mathcal{SR}$: Set of Sprint Reviews (Entity: SprintReview)
    \item $\mathcal{SRE}$: Set of Sprint Retrospectives (Entity: SprintRetrospective)
    \item $\mathcal{SBL}$: Set of Sprint Backlogs (Entity: SprintBacklog)
    \item $\mathcal{SG}$: Set of Sprint Goals (Entity: SprintGoal)
    \item $\mathcal{E}$: Set of Epics (Entity: Epic)
    \item $\mathcal{US}$: Set of User Stories (Entity: UserStory)
    \item $\mathcal{TSK}$: Set of Tasks (Entity: Task)
    \item $\mathcal{DEV}$: Set of Development Snapshots (Entity: DevelopmentSnapshot)
    \item $\mathcal{BL}$: Set of Blockers (Entity: Blocker)
    \item $\mathcal{SH}$: Set of Stakeholders (Entity: Stakeholder)
    \item $\mathcal{VEL}$: Set of Velocity Records (Entity: Velocity)
    \item $\mathcal{REP}$: Set of Release Plans (Entity: ReleasePlan)
    \item $\mathcal{RM}$: Set of Roadmaps (Entity: Roadmap)
    \item $\mathcal{SCB}$: Set of Scrum Boards (Entity: ScrumBoard)
    \item $\mathcal{FED}$: Set of Feature Documentations (Entity: FeatureDocumentation)
\end{itemize}

\section{2. Indices}
\begin{itemize}
    \item $p \in \mathcal{P}$: Index for projects
    \item $t \in \mathcal{T}$: Index for teams
    \item $w \in \mathcal{W}$: Index for workers
    \item $f \in \mathcal{F}$: Index for features
    \item $s \in \mathcal{S}$: Index for skills
    \item $r \in \mathcal{R}$: Index for roles
    \item $po \in \mathcal{PO}$: Index for product owners
    \item $sm \in \mathcal{SM}$: Index for scrum masters
    \item $pb \in \mathcal{PB}$: Index for product backlogs
    \item $sp \in \mathcal{SP}$: Index for sprints
    \item $sbl \in \mathcal{SBL}$: Index for sprint backlogs
    \item $us \in \mathcal{US}$: Index for user stories
    \item $tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}$: Index for tasks
    \item $bl \in \mathcal{BL}$: Index for blockers
    \item $sh \in \mathcal{SH}$: Index for stakeholders
    \item $rep \in \mathcal{REP}$: Index for release plans
    \item $vel \in \mathcal{VEL}$: Index for velocity records
\end{itemize}

\section{3. Goals}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[G0] \texttt{maximize\_completed\_story\_points}: Maximize total completed story points.
    \[
    \max \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} x_{us} \cdot \text{story\_points}(us)
    \]
    where $x_{us} = 1$ if user story $us$ is completed.

    \item[G1] \texttt{maximize\_team\_velocity}: Maximize average team velocity.
    \[
    \max \text{avg\_story\_points}(vel) \quad \text{for } vel \in \mathcal{VEL}
    \]

    \item[G2] \texttt{minimize\_open\_blockers}: Minimize unresolved blockers.
    \[
    \min \sum_{bl \in \mathcal{BL}} (1 - \mathbb{I}[\text{resolved\_on}(bl) > 0])
    \]

    \item[G3] \texttt{maximize\_requirement\_clarity}: Maximize clarity via presence of acceptance criteria.
    \[
    \max \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} \mathbb{I}[\text{acceptance\_criteria}(us) \neq \emptyset]
    \]

    \item[G4] \texttt{maximize\_feature\_delivery\_rate}: Maximize delivered features.
    \[
    \max \sum_{f \in \mathcal{F}} \mathbb{I}[\text{status}(f) = \texttt{"Done"}]
    \]

    \item[G5] \texttt{minimize\_sprint\_goal\_failures}: Minimize failed sprint goals.
    \[
    \min \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \mathbb{I}[\text{achievement\_of\_goal}(sp) = \texttt{"Failed"}]
    \]

    \item[G6] \texttt{maximize\_stakeholder\_participation}: Maximize stakeholder attendance.
    \[
    \max \sum_{sr \in \mathcal{SR}} \text{attendees\_count}(sr)
    \]

    \item[G7] \texttt{minimize\_task\_effort\_deviation}: Minimize estimated vs. actual effort deviation.
    \[
    \min \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \left| \text{actual\_effort}(tsk) - \text{effort}(tsk) \right|
    \]
    (Assume actual effort is observable or estimated post-hoc.)

    \item[G8] \texttt{maximize\_documentation\_coverage}: Maximize documented features.
    \[
    \max \sum_{fed \in \mathcal{FED}} \mathbb{I}[\text{linked\_requirements}(fed) \neq \emptyset]
    \]

    \item[G9] \texttt{maximize\_team\_availability}: Maximize available worker capacity.
    \[
    \max \sum_{w \in \mathcal{W}} \text{availability}(w)
    \]

    \item[G10] \texttt{minimize\_technical\_debt\_accumulation}: Minimize technical debt tasks.
    \[
    \min \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \mathbb{I}[\text{type}(tsk) = \texttt{"technical\_debt"}]
    \]

    \item[G11] \texttt{maximize\_backlog\_refinement\_rate}: Maximize refined backlog entries.
    \[
    \max \text{number\_of\_entries}(pb) \quad \text{for } pb \in \mathcal{PB}
    \]

    \item[G12] \texttt{minimize\_release\_delay}: Minimize release delays.
    \[
    \min \sum_{rep \in \mathcal{REP}} \max(0, \text{actual\_release\_date}(rep) - \text{planned\_date}(rep))
    \]

    \item[G13] \texttt{maximize\_cross\_functionality}: Maximize skill diversity per team.
    \[
    \max \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} |\{ s \in \mathcal{S} \mid \exists w \in t : \text{has\_skill}(w,s) \}|
    \]

    \item[G14] \texttt{minimize\_sprint\_scope\_changes}: Minimize mid-sprint changes.
    \[
    \min \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \text{count\_of\_mid\_sprint\_additions}(sp)
    \]
\end{itemize}

\section{4. Conditions}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[C0] \texttt{assign_worker_to_team}: Each worker assigned to at most one team.
    \[
    \sum_{t \in \mathcal{T}} y_{w,t} \leq 1 \quad \forall w \in \mathcal{W}
    \]
    where $y_{w,t} \in \{0,1\}$ indicates assignment.

    \item[C1] \texttt{task_belongs_to_user_story}: Each task belongs to exactly one user story.
    \[
    \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} z_{tsk,us} = 1 \quad \forall tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}
    \]
    where $z_{tsk,us} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C2] \texttt{user_story_in_sprint_backlog}: A user story can only be in one sprint backlog.
    \[
    \sum_{sbl \in \mathcal{SBL}} a_{us,sbl} \leq 1 \quad \forall us \in \mathcal{US}
    \]
    where $a_{us,sbl} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C3] \texttt{sprint_duration_constraint}: Each sprint lasts between 1 and 4 weeks.
    \[
    7 \leq \text{end\_date}(sp) - \text{start\_date}(sp) \leq 28 \quad \forall sp \in \mathcal{SP}
    \]

    \item[C4] \texttt{worker_skill_requirement}: Workers assigned to tasks must have required skills.
    \[
    y_{w,t} \cdot \text{has\_skill}(w,s) \geq \text{required\_skill}(tsk,s) \cdot x_{tsk}
    \]
    for relevant $w, tsk, s$.

    \item[C5] \texttt{scrum_events_occurrence}: Each sprint must have exactly one planning, review, and retrospective.
    \[
    \exists spp \in \mathcal{SPP}, sr \in \mathcal{SR}, sre \in \mathcal{SRE} : \text{linked to } sp
    \]

    \item[C6] \texttt{product_owner_manages_backlog}: Each product backlog is managed by one PO.
    \[
    \sum_{po \in \mathcal{PO}} b_{pb,po} = 1 \quad \forall pb \in \mathcal{PB}
    \]
    where $b_{pb,po} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C7] \texttt{team_has_scrum_master}: Each team has exactly one Scrum Master.
    \[
    \sum_{sm \in \mathcal{SM}} c_{t,sm} = 1 \quad \forall t \in \mathcal{T}
    \]

    \item[C8] \texttt{task_effort_within_capacity}: Total assigned task effort $\leq$ worker capacity.
    \[
    \sum_{tsk \in \mathcal{TSK}} \text{effort}(tsk) \cdot d_{w,tsk} \leq \text{availability}(w) \quad \forall w \in \mathcal{W}
    \]
    where $d_{w,tsk} \in \{0,1\}$ if worker $w$ does task $tsk$.

    \item[C9] \texttt{epic_contains_user_stories}: Each epic must contain at least one user story.
    \[
    \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} e_{e,us} \geq 1 \quad \forall e \in \mathcal{E}
    \]
    where $e_{e,us} \in \{0,1\}$.

    \item[C10] \texttt{release_plan_includes_features}: Release plan must include only valid features.
    \[
    \text{included\_features}(rep) \subseteq \mathcal{F} \quad \forall rep \in \mathcal{REP}
    \]

    \item[C11] \texttt{velocity_based_on_completed_points}: Velocity must reflect actual completed story points.
    \[
    \text{avg\_story\_points}(vel) = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{SP}|} \sum_{sp \in \mathcal{SP}} \sum_{us \in \mathcal{US}} \text{story\_points}(us) \cdot x_{us,sp}
    \]

    \item[C12] \texttt{daily_scrum_frequency}: At least one Daily Scrum per working day during sprint.
    \[
    |\{ ds \in \mathcal{DS} \mid \text{date}(ds) \in [\text{start\_date}(sp), \text{end\_date}(sp)] \}| \geq \text{working\_days}(sp)
    \]

    \item[C13] \texttt{blocker_resolution_time}: Blockers must be resolved within 3 days.
    \[
    \text{resolved\_on}(bl) - \text{detected\_on}(bl) \leq 3 \quad \forall bl \in \mathcal{BL}
    \]

    \item[C14] \texttt{documentation_must_exist}: Every completed feature must have documentation.
    \[
    \forall f \in \mathcal{F}, \text{if status}(f) = \texttt{"Done"}, \exists fed \in \mathcal{FED} : \text{linked\_requirements}(fed) = f
    \]
\end{itemize}

\section{5. DecisionVariables}
\begin{itemize}
    \item[DV0] $x_{us}$: Completion status of user story $us$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Binary indicator if user story is completed
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV1] $y_{w,t}$: Worker-team assignment
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether worker $w$ is assigned to team $t$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV2] $z_{tsk,us}$: Task-to-user-story mapping
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether task $tsk$ belongs to user story $us$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV3] $a_{us,sbl}$: User story in sprint backlog
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Assignment of user story to sprint backlog
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV4] $b_{pb,po}$: Product Backlog ownership
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether PO manages a given product backlog
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV5] $c_{t,sm}$: Team-Scrum Master assignment
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Assignment of Scrum Master to team
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV6] $d_{w,tsk}$: Task assignment to worker
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether worker $w$ performs task $tsk$
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV7] $e_{e,us}$: Epic-user story membership
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether user story belongs to an epic
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV8] $v_{sp}$: Actual velocity in sprint $sp$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Measured velocity (story points completed)
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 100
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV9] $f_{rep}$: Release delay in days
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Number of days a release is delayed
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 90
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV10] $g_{bl}$: Blocker resolution time
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Duration (days) a blocker remains unresolved
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 10
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV11] $h_{tsk}$: Actual effort spent on task
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Realized effort (e.g., hours) for task
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 40
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV12] $k_{w}$: Availability level of worker $w$
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Weekly available hours
        \item DataType: Continuous
        \item Domain: $[0, 40]$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 40
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV13] $m_{f}$: Documentation status of feature
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Whether documentation exists for feature
        \item DataType: Binary
        \item Domain: $\{0, 1\}$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 1
    \end{itemize}

    \item[DV14] $n_{sp}$: Number of mid-sprint changes
    \begin{itemize}
        \item Description: Count of scope changes during sprint
        \item DataType: Integer
        \item Domain: $[0, \infty)$
        \item MinValue: 0
        \item MaxValue: 20
    \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

\end{document}
```

Transform all of the provided and generated CSV data (Entities, Attributes, Relations, Goals, Conditions, DecisionVariables) into a graph using the Mermaid.js Live Editor graph TD syntax.
Connect...
- Entities with their Attributes and place the Attributes around the Entities they belong to. (can exist multiple times in the graph to make lines less short)
- Entities with their Relations
- Goals with the Entity/Attributes
- Conditions with the Entity/Attributes
- DecisionVariables with their relevant Entities

Colorize...
- Entities in blue
- Attributes in white
- Relations in orange
- Goals in green
- Conditions in red
- Decision Variables in purple

content_list.content:
Here's a **Mermaid.js `graph TD`** representation that integrates **all** the provided and generated 

- Entities (blue)
- Attributes (white)
- Relationships (orange)
- Goals (green)
- Conditions (red)
- Decision Variables (purple)

The graph connects:
- Entities ↔ Attributes
- Entities ↔ Relations
- Goals ↔ Entity + Attribute
- Conditions ↔ Entity + Attribute
- DecisionVariables ↔ Entities

> ✅ This code is designed to be used in the **[Mermaid Live Editor](https://mermaid.live/edit)**. Due to complexity, it’s optimized for readability and structure. For best layout, use `graph TD` with `direction TB` or `direction LR`.

---

```mermaid

    classDef relation fill:#ff8c00,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef goal fill:#2ca02c,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef condition fill:#d62728,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;
    classDef decisionVar fill:#9467bd,stroke:#000,color:white,font-weight:bold;

    %% =============== ENTITIES ===============
    E0[Project]:::entity
    E1[Team]:::entity
    E2[Worker]:::entity
    E3[Feature]:::entity

    R1[is_assigned_to_project]:::relation
```
